risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Veterinary Technology Program, Dalhousie University, Bible Hill, NS, Canada

sect2.title: 3.1 Introduction
sect2.para: When discussing palliative medicine in companion animal end‐of‐life (EOL) care, the treatment of pain is often the first priority. Pain control is a crucial element of patient comfort and well‐being. End‐of‐life patients may experience pain from multiple underlying conditions, and that pain may change as the conditions progress or new conditions are diagnosed. Veterinary technicians play critical roles in pain management as providers of medical care, patient advocates, and client educators. Technicians assess pain, administer prescribed therapies, monitor patient response, advocate for treatment changes, and they also educate and emotionally support caregivers who monitor and treat pain at home.

Once an animal’s pain has been thoroughly assessed, the veterinarian formulates a treatment plan, and the technician supports the implementation of the plan. Effective treatment plans will bemultimodal, addressing pain using multiple complementary strategies with different methods of action. This may include pharmaceuticals, physical modalities, such as massage and laser therapy, and integrative medicine techniques, such as acupuncture and herbal medicine. Complementary and integrative medicine blends all these strategies and is an important tool in companion animal EOL care. More clients are requesting and expecting the inclusion of complementary and integrative medicine in palliative care for their pets.

The strategies for pain recognition and assessment that were discussed inChapter 2 must continually be applied as patients are monitored for changes in their status and their response to adjusted treatments. Pain may change and worsen as disease progresses, and bouts of acute pain can occur in planned (e.g. surgery) or unexpected circumstances (e.g. trauma). Any change requires a reassessment of the patient and potential revision of the treatment plan.

sect2.title: 3.2 Role of Veterinary Technicians and Approach to Pain Management
sect2.para: It is crucial that the pain management plan is made in partnership with caregivers to have the highest chance of compliance. The needs and preferences of both the caregiver and the patient should be considered in the development and implementation of the plan. Examples of these considerations are shown in Table 3.1. A treatment plan may be well thought out from a medical perspective, but if the client is incapable of fully implementing it, then the plan is not appropriate. The stress and effort of caring for pets is referred to as caregiver burden and is a strong predictor of euthanasia. Effective treatment must seek to balance and monitor caregiver burden as part of the plan. Similarly, if the treatment plan is stressful for the patient such that it negatively impacts their quality of life (QOL) and/or the human animal bond (HAB), then the care plan should be modified.

Table 3.1
Caregiver and patient needs and preferences in pain management plan.

entry.para: Financial ability to implement plan (including plans for future changes) Physical ability to administer treatments (e.g. patient handling, medication handling) Time available to administer treatments Mental/emotional ability to commit to plan Sufficient support to implement and maintain plan
Behavioral tolerance of treatments Preferences for routes, formulations, and flavors of medications Impact of treatment on relationship with caregivers

sect2.para: Technicians can be highly effective in maintaining lines of communication between the veterinary team and caregivers to optimize pain management. They can facilitate rapid detection of changes in patient status or response to treatment and communicate them to the veterinarian. Technicians offering telemedicine or in‐person support between veterinarian exams may help expedite treatment plan revisions by the veterinarian in response to patient needs or caregiver burden. Caregivers with an open line of communication with the EOL care team will also be more likely to communicate challenges with caregiver burden, concerns about the care plan, or future decision‐making. Engaged and knowledge EOL technicians have significant potential to improve the patient's QOL and maintain a positive rapport with the caregivers.

EOL patients are often impacted by chronic, neuropathic pain and multiple comorbidities. The treatment plan must effectively account for these comorbidities and seek to address the neuropathic nature of chronic pain where it is present. When implementing a pain management plan, it is important to interrupt the cycle of pain particularly where neuropathic pain is present or at risk of developing. This might involve the short‐term use of drugs, doses, or frequencies that may not form part of the ongoing treatment plan. For example, pharmaceuticals like opioids (e.g. fentanyl or methadone) may be used to control severe pain initially but then be discontinued in favor of other strategies for long‐term pain management. When a pain management plan is implemented, technicians will be vigilant in monitoring patients for their response. Ongoing and regular monitoring allows technicians to continue supporting and educating clients, as well as staying informed about any changes in their patient's status that may require veterinary re‐evaluation. Technicians can advocate for treatment changes for a variety of reasons:

listitem.para: Challenges with caregiver burden and compliance
Negative side effects
Increased stress due to treatments
New or uncontrolled pain
New clinical signs

sect2.title: 3.3 Pharmaceutical Pain Management
sect2.para: Multimodal analgesic plans may involve multiple pharmaceuticals with different mechanisms of action. Nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are often relied upon in both acute and chronic pain. Opioids are most useful in acute pain and pain crises. Adjunctive pain medications such as gabapentinoids, NMDA receptor antagonists, and antidepressants target multiple points in nociceptive pathways to offer more balanced pain management that addresses neuropathic pain. The use of adjunctive analgesics may reduce the doses or frequency of opioids and NSAIDs, thereby minimizing risk of adverse effects and creating capacity for future dose increases.

sect2.title: 3.3.1 NSAIDs
sect2.para: NSAIDs are a mainstay of analgesia in veterinary medicine due to their effect on pain pathways both peripherally and centrally and their direct anti‐inflammatory action. They are an appropriate choice for the treatment of both acute and chronic pain and are a common component of multimodal pain management in EOL patients. They can be combined with other pharmaceutical and nonpharmaceutical strategies, and they lessen reliance on opioids.

The primary effect of NSAIDs is the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX), which is an important enzyme in the process of inflammation. Inhibiting COX inhibits the production of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins. This reduces inflammation and related inflammatory pain at the site of injury or disease. NSAIDs may target both forms of COX (COX‐1 and COX‐2) or they may be more selective for COX‐2, which is more involved in pain and inflammation. COX‐2 selective NSAIDs have a reduced risk of adverse effects that can be associated with COX‐1 inhibition (e.g. gastrointestinal irritation, renal or liver damage). In addition to anti‐inflammatory and analgesic effects at the site of tissue disease or damage, NSAIDs have also been found to act at the level of the spinal cord. NSAIDs can increase descending inhibitory signals to counteract some of the neurophysiological changes associated with neuropathic pain ch0013-c3-bib-0001.

There are a variety of veterinary licensed NSAIDs available in different formulations. Each veterinary team will have products they are more familiar with and use more frequently. However, each patient and caregiver is unique, and the best NSAID is going to be the one that works for them. If a particular NSAID is difficult to administer or the patient experiences adverse effects, it is reasonable for veterinarians to try again with another type of NSAID before excluding them from the treatment plan. Patients prescribed NSAIDs will need to be monitored routinely for changes in their health status, which may trigger revision of the treatment plan. This may include small adjustments such as dosing changes due to level of pain and bodyweight. The use of NSAIDs may need to be re‐evaluated based on the occurrence of adverse effects or changes in organ function (such as diagnosis of liver or kidney dysfunction or the occurrence of gastrointestinal disease). Patients receiving long‐term use of NSAIDs would ideally be monitored with serum biochemistry to monitor liver and kidney function. This is sometimes waived in EOL patients when the caregivers are fully informed about the risks of NSAID use in their pet and they decline further diagnostics in favor of a less invasive care plan.

Examples of common NSAIDs used in companion animals are listed below. Doses can be ascertained from product inserts and readily available drug formularies, and as such are not reported here. The veterinarian may also recommend a dose other than the label dosage (“off label”) for reasons including adjusting to lean body mass, kidney or liver concerns, or titration to lowest effective dose (seePro Tip 3.1).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 3.1 Titrating NSAID Dose to Reserve Capacity
sidebar.para: In patients where pain is well controlled, veterinarians may consider titrating NSAIDs below the label dosage. If a patient's pain is well managed with a multi‐modal approach, and an NSAID dose can be decreased without compromising QOL, this creates capacity to increase the NSAID dose when needed in the future.

listitem.para: COX‐2 selective inhibitors: e.g. meloxicam, carprofen, robenacoxib
COX‐1 sparing inhibitor: e.g. deracoxib
Non‐selective COX inhibitors: e.g. ketoprofen, piroxicam

EP4 receptor antagonist: grapiprant (Galliprant®) is a unique NSAID that targets a prostaglandin receptor (EP4), rather than COX enzymes. This reduces some of the adverse effects associated with COX inhibition ch0013-c3-bib-0002.

sect2.para: Important NSAID Reminders ch0013-c3-bib-0003:
Any deviation from the following recommendations in EOL pets will only be at the discretion of the veterinarian and with informed client consent.

listitem.para: NSAIDs should be given with food and to well‐hydrated patients to minimize adverse effects.
NSAIDs should not be administered to animals in liver or renal failure or with gastrointestinal ulceration.

NSAIDs cannot be mixed with steroids due to the risk of GI ulceration. If a transition from steroids to NSAIDs is occurring, or vice versa, washout periods of three to five days are advised, and gastro‐protectants may also be recommended by the veterinarian.

NSAIDs should not be administered to animals on angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (e.g. benazepril, enalapril, etc.) or diuretics (e.g. furosemide, spironolactone, etc.) as there may be changes in hydration and renal perfusion.

sect2.title: 3.3.2 Opioids
sect2.para: Opioids are a key component of analgesia and the cornerstone of acute pain management, but they are not the first line of therapy for chronic pain. Opioids bind to receptors (mu, kappa, and delta) in the central nervous system. When opioids bind to their target receptors they act to inhibit nociceptive pathways, with opioids that bind primarily to mu receptors having the strongest analgesic effect (Table 3.2). Injectable opioids are fast acting and bioavailable when administered intravenously (IV), intramuscularly (IM), or subcutaneously (SC). They are also used in locoregional anesthesia techniques such as epidural administration. Administration of opioids by other routes (transdermal/TD, oral transmucosal/OTM, oral/PO or rectal/PR) will have more variable absorption into systemic circulation, which is why injectable routes are preferred. For example, fentanyl patches have been widely used in the past, but there are challenges with skin adherence as well as wide variability in absorption and concerns with ingestion toxicity and human abuse. Opioids administered orally to canine patients undergo a significant first pass effect and lose significant efficacy, thus oral opioids are best avoided in dogs.

While opioids are still the first line of therapy for acute and severe pain, they can be accompanied by adverse effects which make them less attractive in long‐term multimodal analgesic plans. Nausea and vomiting are well‐known adverse effects associated with opioid administration. It is less common when patients are already experiencing significant pain but offering antiemetic therapy in conjunction with opioids can improve the patient experience. The following are adverse effects that must be considered when including opioids in a pain management plan ch0013-c3-bib-0003:

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 3.2 Tramadol Inefficacy in Treating Canine Pain

para.emphasis: Tramadol is not an effective analgesic in dogs

blockquote.para: and should not be included in pain management plans.

sidebar.para: Tramadol is an oral opioid analogue that has been widely used in veterinary medicine, particularly in canines, despite its documented lack of bioavailability and analgesic efficacy in these patientsch0013-c3-bib-0005. Tramadol may be used in cats but is not as common as other choices (e.g. OTM buprenorphine).

Tapentadol is a similar compound that is more bioavailable in canines, and there is some evidence for its analgesic efficacych0013-c3-bib-0006. This drug may become more relevant in veterinary analgesia in the future.

sect2.para: The controlled status of opioids makes their use in EOL home care plans challenging from a regulatory standpoint. Before EOL veterinarians prescribe these drugs, it is recommended that caregivers sign additional informed consent forms tailored to the prescription, handling, storage, and responsible use of controlled substances. Developing an approach to the prescription of controlled substances within EOL home care can be valuable in providing effective pain palliation at home. This may be useful when the EOL care team is supporting death at home, either through hospice supported natural death or humane euthanasia. Prescribing opioids for use at home during a pain crisis is also becoming more common in companion animal EOL care, often through the use of “comfort kits.” The opioid in this instance is generally dispensed in a syringe also containing the tranquilizer acepromazine to provide analgesia and mild sedation for patient comfort during a sudden change of patient status that may be associated with an acute exacerbation of pain. The use of a comfort kit may allow the patient to die more peacefully if they are in the active process, or it may provide comfort while awaiting an urgent house call from a veterinarian or arranging transport to a veterinary facility. Comfort kits will be discussed in more detail inChapter 4.

sect2.title: 3.3.3 Corticosteroids
sect2.para: Corticosteroids (e.g. prednisone, prednisolone, and dexamethasone) are potent anti‐inflammatory drugs that can be used in the management of chronic pain with a significant inflammatory component. They may be useful when NSAIDs are not sufficient to manage pain, even within a multimodal strategy. Corticosteroids are not a first‐line therapy as chronic use is accompanied by adverse effects including immunosuppression, increased thirst and urination, endocrine disruption, and muscle wasting. They cannot be used concurrently with NSAIDs as there is a severe risk for GI ulceration. One of the adverse effects of corticosteroid use can be an increased appetite, which may be seen as an advantage in EOL pets. Anti‐inflammatory doses for corticosteroids are readily available in drug references, and will be titrated with patient monitoring to balance anti‐inflammatory efficacy with tolerable adverse effects (e.g. polydipsia, polyuria).

sect2.title: 3.3.4 Gabapentinoids
sect2.para:
Gabapentinoids (gabapentin and pregabalin) are anticonvulsants that also have analgesic effects. The mechanism of action is unclear, but they likely interact with voltage‐gated calcium channels which is a unique target among analgesicsch0013-c3-bib-0007. The interaction of gabapentinoids with these targets leads to reduced release of neurotransmitters, thus altering multiple steps of nociception discussed in
Chapter 2. The central targets of gabapentinoids impact the transmission and modulation of nociceptive signals, and potentially also the perception of pain [ch0013-c3-bib-0008, ch0013-c3-bib-0009]. Some gabapentinoid effects, such as inhibitory nerve receptor upregulation, are slow to develop and require continued administration ch0013-c3-bib-0008. As such, they are more appropriate for chronic pain rather than acute pain management.

Gabapentinoids are a first‐line therapy for neuropathic pain in humans and have been shown to improve neuropathic pain in dogs when combined with NSAIDs [ch0013-c3-bib-0008, ch0013-c3-bib-0010]. They are generally used as an adjunctive analgesic and not as a solo agent. Given their use as anticonvulsants, the addition of gabapentinoids to an analgesic plan can be advantageous in patients with a history of seizures or a condition which may increase the risk of seizure events (e.g. intracranial neoplasia). Gabapentinoids have been shown to have greater efficacy with an improved safety profile in humans when compared to tricyclic antidepressants used for neuropathic pain ch0013-c3-bib-0008.

listitem.para: Gabapentin is the most commonly used gabapentinoid, and likely the most familiar to technicians. It can cause initial sedation and ataxia, but this generally lessens as regular use of gabapentin continues. Reported doses for dogs and cats range from 5 to 20 mg/kg ch0013-c3-bib-0003. Pharmacokinetic and therapeutic evidence support doses of 10 mg/kg PO q8–12 hours, with every 8 hours preferable. Lower doses or frequencies are likely to have reduced efficacy due to the short half‐life of the drug ch0013-c3-bib-0007.

Pregabalin has been used with success in people who did not experience a significant analgesic effect from gabapentin and has been shown effective for neuropathic pain in dogs [ch0013-c3-bib-0007, ch0013-c3-bib-0011]. More research is needed to identify safe and effective doses for dogs and cats, but pharmacokinetic studies suggest doses of 1–2 mg/kg PO every 12 hours for cats and up to 3–4 mg/kg in dogs ch0013-c3-bib-0003.

sect2.title: 3.3.5 NMDA Receptor Antagonists
sect2.para: N‐methyl‐D‐aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonists such asamantadine and ketamine target NMDA receptors in the spinal cord. These receptors are upregulated in neuropathic pain. NMDA receptor antagonists are typically added in cases where the existing chronic pain management plan is deemed insufficient, and where neuropathic pain is present.

Amantadine is becoming a more common component of multimodal pain management, particularly in osteoarthritis. A suggested dose for canine and feline patients is 3 mg/kg PO q24h for an initial period of 21 days prior to re‐evaluation [ch0013-c3-bib-0003, ch0013-c3-bib-0012, ch0013-c3-bib-0013]. Amantadine can impact levels of dopamine and serotonin neurotransmitters in the central nervous system and may not be appropriate in patients receiving other drugs with effects on dopamine and serotonin (e.g. tricyclic antidepressants, selegiline, etc.) to avoid adverse effects of brain overstimulation (serotonin syndrome) ch0013-c3-bib-0007. While veterinarians are responsible for prescribing with consideration for drug interactions, technicians should also be familiar with the contraindications for drugs they commonly dispense and administer.

Ketamine is commonly used in anesthesia and surgery during induction and in CRIs and epidurals, but SC administration at subanesthetic doses has been investigated in multiple canine studies for analgesia outside of a surgical context [ch0013-c3-bib-0014–ch0013-c3-bib-0016]. Research in human medicine has shown subanesthetic ketamine administration to have a significant impact on pain and a reduction in opioid usage ch0013-c3-bib-0017. Its use is being advocated in the treatment of chronic pain and cancer pain in people, and there are anecdotal reports of veterinarians using subanesthetic SC ketamine in EOL pain management ch0013-c3-bib-0018. More research is needed to determine effective doses, frequencies, and indications for subanesthetic ketamine. Anecdotal starting doses are 0.5–1 mg/kg SC weekly or monthly. EOL patients may require increased frequency to initially break the pain cycle or to respond to pain crises, with dosing as often as every 24–48 hrs.

Technicians may see subanesthetic SC ketamine used to manage breakthrough pain, pain crises, and new causes of acute pain to reduce sensitization and the risk of neuropathic pain development. An example of SC ketamine usage in EOL care would be in a canine patient with osteosarcoma. If a patient's pain has been well managed, but they suddenly experience a pathological fracture, a subanesthetic injection of SC ketamine and an opioid (e.g. methadone or hydromorphone) may be appropriate. This gives time for the family to discuss options with the EOL care team while the pet's comfort is effectively addressed.

sect2.title: 3.3.6 Other Adjunctive Analgesics
sect2.para: Acetaminophen (or paracetamol) is a commonly used adjunctive analgesic in canine patients but is toxic to cats. It primarily targets the brain and spinal cord, likely through selective COX‐3 inhibition. This variant of cyclooxygenase appears to be primarily expressed in the brain and its inhibition leads to the analgesic and antipyretic effects that differentiate acetaminophen from NSAIDs ch0013-c3-bib-0019. Acetaminophen also indirectly acts on the endocannabinoid system ch0013-c3-bib-0020. It can be used as a solo agent and is available in combination products with oral opioids, such as hydrocodone in Vicodin®. Given the low oral bioavailability of opioids in dogs, use of the solo agent is preferred unless a sedative or antitussive effect is also desired. Acetaminophen is commonly used on an as‐needed, adjunctive basis in pain management plans. It can be useful as an additional line of therapy for “bad days” or breakthrough pain in dogs whose pain is otherwise well controlled. It can be used in conjunction with NSAIDs, but caution should be used in patients with hepatic, renal, or gastrointestinal disease ch0013-c3-bib-0003. Canine dose range is 10–15 mg/kg PO q8–12h [ch0013-c3-bib-0003, ch0013-c3-bib-0004].

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that can be used in the adjunctive therapy of neuropathic pain as it blocks the reuptake of neurotransmitters (serotonin and norepinephrine) ch0013-c3-bib-0004. It can be a helpful addition to a pain plan addressing central sensitization and may have an added advantage for patients who experience anxiety. Amitriptyline is contraindicated with a history of or risk of seizures. Other psychoactive medications are used in human analgesia, but evidence in veterinary species is currently lacking. Caution must be exercised when administering amitriptyline concurrently with other drugs that may impact neurotransmitters (e.g. tramadol, trazodone, selegiline, etc.), and amitriptyline should not be discontinued suddenly but should instead be slowly tapered. Dose recommendations include 1–2 mg/kg PO q12–24h for canine patients and 0.5–2 mg/kg PO q12–24h for feline patients [ch0013-c3-bib-0003, ch0013-c3-bib-0004].

Maropitant is an antiemetic drug that has been recently investigated for visceral analgesic effects. While there is some evidence for visceral analgesia, there is no apparent anti‐inflammatory effect ch0013-c3-bib-0021. The current evidence for maropitant as an analgesic is minimal, but this could be a factor in its favor when considering inclusion in a treatment plan for antiemetic purposes. Maropitant citrate can accumulate in the body, and washout periods of 48 hours are recommended after 5 days of continuous use ch0013-c3-bib-0003. Veterinarians prescribing maropitant to EOL patients will weigh this recommendation against the QOL benefit of continued treatment in advanced hospice. Label doses are used and technicians will take care to ensure comfortable administration (Pro Tip 3.3).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 3.3 Comfortable Maropitant Administration
sidebar.para: Maropitant injections can cause discomfort but are better tolerated when the drug is refrigerated compared to room temperature ch0013-c3-bib-0007. Administer maropitant cold. Do not warm it in the syringe prior to injection.

sect3.title: 3.3.6.1 Local Anesthesia
sect3.para: Local anesthesia is typically thought of in the context of surgery, and there is certainly a need for a high standard of pain management in EOL patients undergoing surgical procedures (e.g. line blocks, nerve blocks, epidurals, wound infusion catheters, etc.). There are many opportunities to offer local anesthesia for pain management in EOL patients outside of surgery. Long‐acting local anesthetics (i.e. liposomal bupivacaine) may improve pain control in circumstances such as home care for chronic wounds. Lidocaine patches and topical creams (EMLA®) may be helpful adjuncts in painful wounds or superficial ulcers. Lidocaine is anecdotally used in mouth rinses for cats with painful oral lesions (e.g. squamous cell carcinoma). Patches and creams must be well covered to prevent patient ingestion, and mouth rinses including lidocaine must be carefully dosed to avoid toxicity concerns.

sect3.title: 3.3.6.2 Monoclonal Antibody Therapy
sect3.para: Solensia™ (frunevetmab) for cats and Librela™ (bedinvetmab) for dogs are monoclonal antibody therapies used in the management of osteoarthritis pain. Veterinarians treating canine osteoarthritis patients report positive patient response to bedinvetmab and less reliance on multiple analgesic drugs ch0013-c3-bib-0022. Validated QOL assessments have shown improvement in both cats and dogs treated with frunevetmab and bedinvetmab, respectively ch0013-c3-bib-0023. Monoclonal antibody therapies may be considered an attractive option as they are not drugs per se, but rare reports of adverse effects with Librela™ emphasize the importance of informed consent with these products as with any other treatment ch0013-c3-bib-0024.

sect3.title: 3.3.6.3 Bisphosphonates
sect3.para: Bisphosphonates (e.g. pamidronate, zoledronate, alendronate, etc.) are compounds that have been shown to induce canine osteosarcoma cell apoptosis and may inhibit tumor growth, thereby relieving bone pain associated with neoplasiach0013-c3-bib-0025. Bisphosphonates can have toxic impacts on the kidneys and must be administered carefully to avoid this (slow, timed IV administration). When used properly, most dogs do not experience adverse effects and the use of bisphosphonates may also positively impact hypercalcemia of malignancy, which can further improve QOL in these patients ch0013-c3-bib-0026.

These drugs can be combined with chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy for pain relief where caregivers have pursued these options. If bisphosphonates and palliative radiation are used in conjunction, there is evidence of improved bisphosphonate efficacy when administered 24 hours following radiationch0013-c3-bib-0027. The concurrent use of radiation and bisphosphonates may not impact survival time compared to radiation alone, but further investigation may indicate whether patients experience improved QOL during this time ch0013-c3-bib-0028.

sect3.title: 3.3.6.4 Cannabidiol
sect3.para: There is increasing interest from caregivers in using cannabis products in their pet's pain management as well as relief from other clinical signs. Cannabis plants contain many bioactive compounds, the most widely known and researched beingdelta‐9‐tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD). The effects of THC are psychoactive, whereas CBD is of greater interest for its potential medicinal purposes ch0013-c3-bib-0029. Cannabinoid receptors are found in all animals (except insects) and are present in greatest numbers in the central nervous system and immune cells, while also being expressed in smaller numbers in many other tissues [ch0013-c3-bib-0030, ch0013-c3-bib-0031].

The potential value of CBD in human medicine is being investigated in multiple contexts including symptom relief in chronic pain, inflammation, cancer, epilepsy, and gastrointestinal disease ch0013-c3-bib-0030. A much more limited body of evidence is available for cannabis use and safety in animals and what is available is focused mostly on canines and laboratory animals. Based on the understanding of the endocannabinoid system in animals, there is potential for CBD to have clinical impacts on anxiety and stress, inflammation, pain, metabolism, cancer, neurodegenerative disease, and possibly cardiovascular and pulmonary function ch0013-c3-bib-0031. A significant investment in peer‐reviewed clinical research is needed before cannabinoids can be broadly implemented in evidence based veterinary medicine, particularly with regards to safe dosage recommendations. Regardless, caregivers may choose to use CBD in their animals at their own risk outside of veterinary recommendation. Thus, it is important for veterinary teams to maintain a positive rapport and open lines of communication around these compounds. It will also be important for teams to remain up to date as new research is published on their use. This will allow veterinarians and technicians to offer guidance on cannabis products as their use becomes more common.

Published evidence is available for positive benefits of CBD in canine osteoarthritis pain ch0013-c3-bib-0032, and there is also evidence that CBD use may have an immunosuppressive effect in dogs. This could be advantageous for inflammatory conditions but could be a concern for inhibiting immune responses to a patient's detriment, for instance in cancer patients ch0013-c3-bib-0033. It is important for veterinary teams and caregivers to be aware that there is documentation of the toxic effects of THC on dogs, who have higher number of cannabinoid receptors and are more sensitive to the effects of THC [ch0013-c3-bib-0031, ch0013-c3-bib-0034]. If cannabis products are used in companion animal EOL care, they must be CBD products without THC content.

The regulation and availability of cannabis products varies between and within countries. Veterinary teams must be aware of their regulatory context when recommending products to caregivers. Some products contain CBD extracted from hemp oil and may be available in areas where marijuana products are otherwise prohibited. The regulation and quality control of such products and the reliability of the listed active ingredients may be questionable, and caution is advised. Doses of CBD up to 20 mg/kg/day have been found to be safe in dogs, and veterinarians report anecdotal starting doses of 5 mg/kg/day ch0013-c3-bib-0035.

sect2.title: 3.4 Physical Modalities
sect2.para: Physical therapy and rehabilitation practices can reduce pain and inflammation and improve function, thereby improving QOL for EOL patientsch0013-c3-bib-0036. Veterinary professionals trained and certified in these services can broaden the scope of the EOL interdisciplinary team. Physical therapy and rehabilitation techniques are medical procedures that should only be performed when prescribed by a veterinarian and administered by trained professionals. Some of the techniques described here are simple and easy to learn with continuing education, and some require more specialized equipment and training. The information provided in this section is meant to inform technicians about available options and would not be sufficient to implement all of these modalities without further training. Technicians interested in training can seek out the Academy of Physical Rehabilitation Veterinary Technicians™, Goldberg and Tomlinson's Physical Rehabilitation for Technicians and Nurses ch0013-c3-bib-0036, and other reputable sources of continuing education.

Even if they are not trained to offer physical therapy themselves, technicians with awareness of the services in their area are able to explore more options with families and facilitate referrals where appropriate. Physical therapy is used most often in canine and equine patients but can certainly be applied in feline patients as well. Cats may not tolerate staying still for treatments and may have more pronounced behavioral responses than dogs or horses. If approached with patience and flexibility on the part of the EOL care team, cats can sometimes be good candidates for physical therapy.

listitem.para: Massage and soft tissue mobilization (STM) is the manual manipulation of tissues to promote normal function. STM is a more systematic and targeted approach compared to massage ch0013-c3-bib-0036. Tui‐na is a branch of Traditional Chinese Veterinary Medicine (TCVM) involving massage.

Myofascial trigger point release is performed by repeatedly applying pressure to painful or tense focal points (i.e. “knots”) in muscle until a release is noted. Trigger points may be manually targeted with hands or other physical modalities (e.g. electrotherapy, therapeutic ultrasound, shockwave therapy, or acupuncture).
Chiropractics involves spinal manipulation to relieve pain and improve range of motion.

Joint range of motion (ROM) techniques move joints through their normal range of flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and internal/external rotation. This can be performed entirely by a therapist or caregiver without muscle activation from the patient (passive ROM), or the patient may be engaged in the movement (active ROM).
Stretching involves the movement of muscle fibers to their normal range of extension.
Therapeutic exercise involves targeted and supported exercises to maintain and improve neuromuscular function and reduce musculoskeletal pain (e.g. sit and stand repetitions).

sect2.title: 3.4.2 Thermotherapy
sect2.para: Thermotherapy utilizes heat and cold to alter tissue temperature with the goal of influencing local biological processes or tissue pliabilitych0013-c3-bib-0036. While the use of thermotherapy may seem straightforward, it does need to be provided in the right way and at the right time to maximize benefit and minimize harm. As with any treatment, thermotherapy should be prescribed and guided by veterinary recommendations. Its use may be contraindicated in certain cases (e.g. patients with reduced sensation or mobility that may be unable to move away from harmful heat or cold; patients with active bleeding, open wounds, or tumors; febrile patients, and patients with severe cardiovascular disease). Thermotherapy should generally be time limited (10–20 minutes) and within a regulated temperature range to avoid tissue damage from heat or cold. Some patients will benefit more from cold (e.g. acute swelling or pain), others more from heat (e.g. stiffness) and some from a combination of both.

listitem.para: Cryotherapy causes vasoconstriction (followed by vasodilation when cold is removed) and temporarily slows cell metabolism, which may reduce inflammation and nerve conductivity. Cryotherapy may also slow degradative enzymes that damage tissues such as cartilage. It can be applied through cold packs, cold water, or even cooling topical sprays or ointments ch0013-c3-bib-0036.

Heat therapy causes vasodilation and can be used to promote healing and to aid in tissue pliability prior to manipulation. It can also speed degradative enzymes that damage tissues and must be used with caution. Possible devices include heat packs, heating pads, heat lamps and warm water ch0013-c3-bib-0036.

sect2.title: 3.4.3 Therapeutic Laser
sect2.para: Laser therapy is becoming more common in veterinary medicine and is available in many general and specialist practices, not just physical rehabilitation facilities. Therapeutic lasers are of a different class than those used for surgical techniques. A more detailed examination of classes of lasers and their mechanisms of action is beyond the scope of this section. For our purposes, we will simply state that laser therapy relies on a process called photobiomodulation where light is applied to tissue with the goal of impacting cellular processes. Therapeutic lasers impact the inflammatory process in each of its stages. It can enhance the immune response to tissue damage, reduce the production of inflammatory cytokines, and overall promote faster tissue healing ch0013-c3-bib-0036. While healing is not the end goal of animal hospice, reduced inflammation and tissue damage is important in palliative care for EOL patients (Figure 3.1). It should be noted that laser therapy is contraindicated with neoplastic tissue as it may promote vascularization and tumor growth.

sect2.para: NOTE: Laser therapy requires additional training, but that training can often be provided by the manufacturer of the equipment and by other trained veterinary professionals already familiar with its use. Ensure you are familiar with the safety precautions and treatment parameters specific to the equipment you are using, and only use it as recommended by the manufacturer and the prescribing veterinarian. Lasers can cause eye damage if used without proper safety protocols.

sect2.title: 3.4.4 Electrotherapy
sect2.para: Electrotherapy is the electrical stimulation of tissue with the goal of reducing muscle atrophy, improving muscle function, and reducing pain and swelling. Further studies are required for specific evidence‐based recommendations regarding which modalities and treatment protocols are most beneficial for a given veterinary species and diagnosis, but electrotherapy is commonly used in veterinary physiotherapy. Inneuromuscular stimulation (NMS) and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) electrodes are applied to a patient and a low level of electrical current is moved between the electrodes in the area to be treated. The stimulation of muscles (NMS) can improve neuromuscular function and improve the flow of blood and lymph through the affected areas (Figure 3.2). Sensory nerve transmission may be impacted by TENS to manage pain in the treated area ch0013-c3-bib-0036.

Figure 3.2

textobject.phrase: A veterinarian gently holds a golden retriever's leg while applying electrodes to its back, with a device nearby.

sect2.para: These therapies require specialized equipment and should only be performed by veterinary professionals trained in their use, with the recommendation of a veterinarian. There are many documented benefits of NMS and TENS when used correctly, but technicians need to be aware of some important patient safety information. Electrical stimulation should not be used over the neck, near the carotid arteries, or over the heart as cardiovascular complications can result. Patients with a history of thrombosis and seizures should not receive electrotherapy. Treatment should be avoided in areas of reduced sensation where patients' response to excess stimulation and potential damage would be masked [ch0013-c3-bib-0003, ch0013-c3-bib-0036]. Technicians trained in the use of electrotherapy will monitor patients closely, as pets that are surprised by the electrical stimulation may show minor, transient signs of aggression. The list of contraindications and cautions should not deter EOL care teams from seeking the benefits of electrotherapy for patients whose caregivers are willing. It simply emphasizes the need for knowledgeable, skillful physiotherapy professionals to be included in the interdisciplinary EOL care team to ensure this therapy is appropriately implemented.

Pulsed electromagnetic field therapy (PEMF) is another method of electrotherapy that creates electromagnetic fields to penetrate tissue and promote healing. PEMF has been shown to reduce pain and inflammation and can be used in cases such as wound healing, osteoarthritis, and intervertebral disc disease ch0013-c3-bib-0036. There are commercially available veterinary PEMF devices (i.e. Assisi Loop and Assisi Lounge®) (Figure 3.3). The manufacturer provides treatment protocols on their website, which veterinary teams can access to help advise clients on the proper use of the device in their pet. PEMF is less localized and specific than NMS and TENS and the short‐term results may be more modest. With that said, PEMF can be readily used in the home environment and caregivers can be trained to use the device themselves. There are no contraindications to its use, which makes it an attractive option to include in home‐based EOL pain management plans where other physical therapy and rehabilitation options may be limited due to lack of available trained personnel or cost limitations.

sect2.title: 3.4.5 Therapeutic Ultrasound and Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy
sect2.para: Therapeutic ultrasound uses sound waves to affect cells and physiological processes. This can include improving blood flow and tissue healing, stimulating scar tissue organization, promoting tissue extensibility, and reducing pain (Figure 3.4) [ch0013-c3-bib-0003, ch0013-c3-bib-0036]. Therapeutic ultrasound is performed with a different device than diagnostic imaging which produces lower frequencies and no image. Operators will require training in its usage.

sect2.para: Extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) employs sound waves similar to therapeutic ultrasound, but in a pulsed manner with higher‐energy sound waves and no image production. The pulses stimulate the release of healing factors in tissue due to the stress that they cause on a cellular level ch0013-c3-bib-0036. The use of ESWT is most common in equine medicine but is also used in companion animals (primarily dogs). It is typically applied in the therapy of tendon and ligament injuries. It may be less common in EOL care plans than therapeutic ultrasound but could still be useful in some cases involving degenerative joint disease.

sect2.title: 3.4.6 Acupuncture
sect2.para: Acupuncture is a branch of TCVM that is widely sought by pet caregivers as a nonpharmaceutical method to address pain. Stimulation of acupuncture points has multiple possible effects: release of endogenous opioids, reduced pain, promotion of immune cell migration, decreased production of inflammatory mediators, and spinal cord effects (reduction of nociception signaling through multiple mechanisms) ch0013-c3-bib-0037. There is evidence for the beneficial effects of acupuncture (including at the level of the spinal cord) which can be included in pain management plans, including those for neuropathic pain. Acupuncture points may be stimulated in a variety of ways. Some of the most common methods in veterinary medicine include dry needling, electroacupuncture (Figure 3.5), manual pressure (acupressure), and therapeutic laser.

sect2.title: 3.5 Nutrition, Nutraceuticals, and Herbal Medicine
sect2.para: Nutrition, nutraceuticals, and herbal medicine can all play a role in a mutimodal pain management plan and are often employed to address the underlying disease processes that are causing the patient's pain.

sect2.title: 3.5.1 Nutrition
sect2.para: Weight management is a key component of osteoarthritis pain management. Caregivers should be offered specific dietary recommendations, weight management goals, and monitoring tools such as body condition scores. Acknowledgement that offering food and treats is a significant part of the HAB will help to address caregiver concerns and improve compliance. Implement weight management programs in a way that will support the HAB (e.g. low calorie treats, exercise together, etc.).

Dietary omega‐3 fatty acids, docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), can have an anti‐inflammatory effect and are often part of multimodal management of inflammatory pain. Dose recommendations range from 50 to 220 mg/kg and while some sources discuss the importance of omega‐3 to omega‐6 ratios, the total quantity of omega‐3 is likely more important ch0013-c3-bib-0038.

Prescription joint diets are available for veterinary prescription diet manufacturers, and there are multiple diets for both canine and feline patients with scientific evidence for their benefits in managing degenerative joint disease. Additional supplementation with omega fatty acids and chrondroprotectants is recommended to achieve therapeutic doses even with prescription diets.

sect2.title: 3.5.2 Chondroprotectants
sect2.para: Polysulfated glycogsaminoglycans and their components glucosamine and chondroitin are often administered as therapies for degenerative joint disease, with the goal of slowing degradation of articular cartilage and improving the quality of synovial fluid. The scientific evidence for their efficacy is inconclusive and contradictory, but as they are generally well tolerated with no significant risks they are often included in multimodal management of osteoarthritis. If cost is an issue in the development of the treatment plan, these therapies may be discontinued in favor of including modalities with more scientific evidence of efficacy (e.g. NSAIDs).

sect2.title: 3.5.3 Herbal Medicine
sect2.para: Herbal medicine can refer to either TCVM or western herbal medicine, or a combination of both. Many clients are interested in the inclusion of alternative therapies such as herbal medicine, and there is scientific evidence to support the use of many herbal remedies. Veterinary teams lacking knowledge of herbal medicine may consult with veterinarians trained in these areas, or they may seek training for their own professional development. A detailed look at evidence‐based herbal analgesics is beyond the scope of this section but technicians can seek out continuing education and contact the College of Integrative Veterinary Therapies for further training. Suggested resources include Complementary Medicine for Veterinary Technicians and Nurses by Scanlonch0013-c3-bib-0039 and Veterinary Herbal Medicine by Wynn and Fougere ch0013-c3-bib-0040.

sect2.title: 3.6.1 “Leo” – Canine Osteosarcoma
sect2.para: Leo is a nine‐year‐old, 45 kg Bernese Mountain Dog previously diagnosed with elbow dysplasia and associated osteoarthritis. Leo was prescribed the following treatments by his regular veterinarian:

listitem.para: Prescription joint diet
Meloxicam 0.1 mg/kg PO q24h
Aquatherapy (underwater treadmill) weekly

sect2.para: The physiotherapist referred Leo back to the regular veterinarian due to an exacerbation of his lameness and a lump noted around his elbow. Radiograph shows presumptive osteosarcoma affecting his right humerus.

listitem.para: Gabapentin 600 mg PO q8–12h is prescribed
Amputation, chemotherapy, and radiation are declined by the caregivers, as is further in hospital care
The family is referred to a home care service for monitoring and palliative care

sect2.para: The home care veterinarian assesses Leo's mobility and pain and finds moderate pain still present. The caregivers also express QOL concerns with Leo showing reduced interaction, more sleeping, and decreased mobility. After discussion with the caregivers, they agree to the following additions to Leo's treatment plan:

listitem.para: IV pamidronate once monthly, administered at home by a veterinary technician
Mobile massage service every two weeks to help ease muscle tension and pain from weight shifting/compensation
Acetaminophen 500 mg PO as needed up to q8–12h with instructions to contact the team for re‐evaluation if it is needed regularly
Comfort kit with two doses of acepromazine 0.02 mg/kg + hydromorphone 0.1 mg/kg to be given SC in the event of acute pain crisis (most likely pathologic fracture)
Weekly completion and reporting of a pain score agreed upon by the caregivers and technician

sect2.para: Leo responds well to the first bisphosphonate treatment, but on the second attempt there is difficultly placing the IV catheter as Leo seems to be reacting painfully to minor handling.

listitem.para: The technician contacts the veterinarian who prescribes 0.5 mg/kg ketamine SC to be administered 30 minutes prior to the next attempt at bisphosphate treatment. The area is clipped and EMLA™ cream is applied for 15–20 minutes to help numb the area prior to catheterization. The catheter placement and bisphosphonate treatment proceed smoothly.

sect2.para: For the next two months, Leo's pain seems well managed with the above treatments until one day the family calls the technician and reports that Leo is panting heavily and cannot get up. With guidance over the phone, the caregivers manage to determine that Leo's heart rate is 140 bpm, and his gums are pink. The technician advises the caregiver to administer the comfort kit and schedules an emergency home visit with the veterinarian.

The veterinarian is unable to reach the family until later that day, but the technician goes to assess Leo in the meantime. It is determined on arrival that Leo is still mildly tachycardiac with a heart rate of 124 after the comfort kit two hours ago. He seems very painful around his right elbow and vocalizes with any handling. The technician is suspicious of a pathological fracture and updates the veterinarian by phone.

listitem.para: The veterinarian directs the technician to administer a 0.5 mg/kg dose SC ketamine and a second dose of the comfort kit to keep Leo comfortable until her arrival.

sect2.para: While awaiting the veterinarian, the family indicates to the technician that they feel it is time to help Leo die peacefully and they ask to begin planning for human euthanasia and aftercare. The veterinarian arrives and the team proceeds with a peaceful euthanasia. The caregivers express how much it meant to them that they had a plan to keep Leo comfortable at home despite the sudden pathological fracture.

sect2.title: 3.6.2 “BB” – Feline Osteoarthritis and Intestinal Lymphoma
sect2.para: BB is a 14‐year‐old, domestic medium hair, female spayed cat that has been diagnosed with osteoarthritis affecting both hips. BB has been on oral robenacoxib tablets for six months for pain management. This significantly helped her QOL when it was started, but lately BB has been having some gastrointestinal signs (inappetence, diarrhea) and her energy level and mobility have both noticeably declined. BB's caregiver, Mandeep, calls their veterinary clinic, and the technician advises to discontinue the oral NSAID due to the inappetence and GI signs and schedules an appointment for a recheck.

The veterinarian is concerned that BB has lost 0.8 kg body weight since her last examination, and there appears to be thickened loops of intestine on abdominal palpation. An ultrasound is performed and there is concern for intestinal lymphoma on the images. Mandeep declines confirmation of the diagnosis with surgical biopsy and referral to an oncologist in favor of a hospice and palliative care approach based on the presumptive diagnosis.

listitem.para: The veterinarian advises to discontinue the robenacoxib entirely given BB's decreased appetite and GI signs which will increase the risk of adverse effects.

Prednisolone is prescribed at 1 mg/kg PO q24h for its anti‐inflammatory benefits both for the presumed neoplasia and the osteoarthritis. Since BB's NSAID was discontinued over five days ago, a washout period has already been completed. The veterinarian is hopeful that the steroid may also improve BB's appetite.

Gabapentin is prescribed at 10 mg/kg PO q8h for a multimodal approach to pain management which will address neuropathic pain that is likely to be present. The technician advises the caregiver that gabapentin may cause sedation or even lack of coordination (ataxia) in the first one to two weeks of treatment, but it should lessen as time goes on.
Mandeep is provided with the feline grimace score and BEAP pain scores to monitor BB’s pain.

sect2.para: The technician calls Mandeep to check in on BB after two weeks and see how she is responding to the prednisolone and gabapentin. BB is doing well with minimal pain on both scores but is quite sedated from the gabapentin, and it is altering her normal behaviors. She has tried to jump up to her favorite window a few times but has been too uncoordinated and has had a few falls which made her more painful afterward. In addition, Mandeep is having difficulty administering the gabapentin three times daily as they work 12 hour shifts and are missing doses. The technician discusses with the veterinarian to see if a change in treatment plan might better serve the needs of BB and her caregiver.

listitem.para: The gabapentin is discontinued and replaced with a trial of amantadine at 3 mg/kg PO q24h.
Buprenorphine is dispensed at 0.02 mg/kg OTM up to once every four to six hours to manage instances of acute pain.

sect2.para: The technician calls to check on BB again in one week and Mandeep is much happier with how she is doing and is managing the treatment plan well. They would like to know what else they can do to improve and maintain BB's quality of life. The technician asks if they would be interested in referral for some alternative therapy such as massage and acupuncture. The caregiver is very excited about the notion and asks for the technician to start that process.

sect2.title: 3.7 Exotic Pet Pain Management
sect2.para: Many species of animals may be cherished companions including small mammals, reptiles, amphibians, birds, fish, and even invertebrates such as tarantulas. Veterinary teams may be called upon to help relieve discomfort and support EOL for “exotic” pets. Wherever possible, exotic pet species should be referred to veterinary teams with special interest and education in their care. Local exotic and alternative pet practices often provide continuing education to other veterinary professionals in their area who may help support emergencies or EOL transitions in these species. There is no shame in admitting a lack of knowledge or skill and setting appropriate professional boundaries is laudable. With that said, veterinary teams that possess a willingness to learn some basic exotic pet care can help caregivers and their companions that might otherwise lack veterinary support.

Technicians should review updated drug formularies and anatomical references before attempting to administer treatment or provide nursing care to these species. Analgesic doses for more commonly encountered alternative pets are available in formularies, and interested veterinary teams can seek them out as needed. NSAIDs and opioids are commonly used in vertebrate species, with evidence‐based recommendations available for many species.

sect2.title: 3.8 Caregiver Education and Communication
sect2.para: Effective communication regarding pain management between technicians and caregivers improves the caregivers' rapport with the veterinary team, reduces caregiver anxiety, helps to dispel myths and misconceptions about pain, and leads to improvements in QOL for the pet. When communicating with caregivers about pain management, it is important that technicians:

listitem.para: Ensure clients understand the details of the treatment plan and are prepared to implement it
Provide resources such information handouts and treatment videos for reference when the veterinary team is no longer present
Ensure clients understand how to monitor for adverse effects
Follow‐up regularly (caregiver pain scoring, telemedicine consults, in home visits) to assess patient response to treatment and change in status
Assure caregivers that the plan can change according to their pet's needs and their needs
Assess caregiver burden regularly
Be flexible and creative in addressing patient and caregiver needs
Technicians are crucial to effective pain management as medical providers, client communicators, and patient advocates.
Caregiver compliance with pain management plans is improved when both caregiver limitations and patient preferences are considered.
Pain management plans will seek to address the underlying cause of pain, neuropathic pain, and include plans for managing breakthrough pain.
Effective multimodal pain management includes pharmaceuticals and complementary and integrative veterinary medicine.
Physical therapy is an important tool in pain management, and simple methods are available as well as those that require specialized equipment and training.
Pain control strategies must be evaluated for response to treatment and re‐evaluated with routine monitoring and any changes in patient status.
Regular communication between the technician and caregivers promotes rapport and trust, faster reporting of patient changes, and overall better QOL for the pet and caregiver.
